data.text: over the last 10 years I refurbished more than 250 older, neglected bicycles mostly from the 1970 -90s. With vegetable oil, like sunflower, rape-seed or low-grade olive oil these rosty drives are turned into functional bicycles within a few minutes. Just pour the oil on the moving chain, then change the gears so the oil is spread over the whole drivetrain. Vegetable oils are a miracle on rosty drivechains. Everything else takes too much time. It is a joy to refurbish drivetrains in the shortest time ! This application should be common knowledge.

data.text: My strategy is to clean it and lube it monthly. Not sticking close to plan but it still is acceptable. A bit noisy, though. When camping, it might be a good idea to cover it with something. In many cases, the bike can look like salvaged from the bottom of a lake, in the morning. Condensation can be heavy. But as long as it has a thin layer of oil, wax or grease (whatever floats your boat), it shouldn't have serious issues. And, after all, judging from the way you asked, I suppose you don't do longer than one week trips. So, having the bike maintained on a monthly basis will ensure it won't look like in the illustration üôÇ If I were you, I'd be mroe concerned of accumulating experience instead of preparing. Meaning: experiment with different maintenance schedules and tools. Try not to find the perfect one from the start.

data.text: Hey. We are on our second 'largish' bike tour (3 months) and have been thinking about the oiling frequency. Like others say it's not really a rust issue that we do it for (on a short term basis anyway) but I think more for length of chain life / reduction in friction etc. I find that the bikes need a drop of oil every 3-4 days of riding which is based on them starting to jump gears a bit (and the oil settles this down again so I assume it's the cause and solution but I'm no bike mechanic!!). The second important thing is the road surface... Sandy/ gravel roads seem to pick up huge amounts of sand very quickly which you can feel grinding away at the chain etc, so I have taken to pretty much a 'proper' weekly clean/ oil in such circumstances (less so if just on roads). An answer to a slightly different question but may be useful to someone!
